central_thesis: This issue of The Scroll of Set serves as an internal guide for Setians, emphasizing the practical application of Setian philosophy through dedicated magical work, adherence to the Temple's structured initiatory path, and critical self-reflection on internal practices and external communication. It promotes personal evolution, self-integration, and active participation in the Temple while also clarifying its unique magical and organizational tenets.

structure_content.chapter_title: Two Thoughts from the Guardians' Chair
structure_content.summary: This section, written by Lilith Sinclair IV°, addresses two key areas for Temple members: 'On Priorities' stresses the importance of dedicating 'reasonable' time and energy to the Black Arts, criticizing members who consistently prioritize mundane activities over Temple functions. 'On Recruiting' encourages Setians to be aware of potential new members among those they encounter in daily life, emphasizing the responsibility to make them aware of the Temple's existence without proselytizing.

structure_content.chapter_title: Dare You Partake of The Dark Side?
structure_content.summary: This short piece introduces Michael A. Aquino's 1981 compilation 'The Dark Side,' using Star Wars as an analogy to suggest a different perspective on power. It notes the compilation is not for commercial sale and is not officially authorized by Lucasfilm Ltd.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Virtue in Vice, or Master Speaks
structure_content.summary: Lynn Norton IV° clarifies several internal Temple tools and methods for Adepts. It discusses the Crystal Tablet of Set (a text with a required reading list for understanding Setian philosophy and magic) and the Ruby Tablet of Set (a platform for member contributions). It explains the 'Pyramid System' as an initiatory schooling model with assigned Priests for guidance and elaborates on the 'Degree System' (Iº, IIº, IIIº, IVº), highlighting that each degree has specific lessons and an æonic Word (Thelema, Xeper, Xem) that must be mastered for proper progression.

Constance L. Moffatt III° emphasizes the significant personal growth and Xeper experienced through attending Temple Conclaves, arguing that personal contact and exchange are invaluable and cannot be replaced by letters or phone calls. She urges members to prioritize attendance despite potential sacrifices.

structure_content.chapter_title: III° Recognitions: Roger Whitaker & Willie Browning
structure_content.summary: Announces the recognition of Roger L. Whitaker and Willie M. Browning as Priests of Set (III°).
Announces the recognition of Amber Shelley as an Adept (II°).

Robertt Neilly III° provides a poetic reflection on personal evolution within the Temple, describing a journey of self-discovery, assimilation by Set, and the realization of one's inner Black Flame through a 'painful evolution' of consciousness.
A brief affirmation by Robert H. Moffatt III° stating 'Nor the coming nor the going of any one of yours shall tear my roots, for my foundation is Me.'
Lists members (Thomas Schneider, Richard Arbib, J. David Furcean, Linda S. Thomas, and Linda Reynolds) who have formally parted from the Temple of Set.

Ricco A. Zappitelli III° details the process of raising one's energy level for self-integration and magical work. He outlines three basic compulsions (security, sensation, power) that deplete energy and explains how to transform them into 'indulgence' to add to one's energy, ultimately leading to the experience of the 'eternal now' and becoming a 'sound magician'.

Corey S. Cole II° proposes a re-examination of Temple terminology, suggesting more precise terms like 'Setian magic' instead of 'Black Magic' and 'ritual magic' or 'traditional magic' instead of 'White Magic.' He advocates for abandoning terms like 'Devil worshipper' to reflect the Temple's evolved understanding and to reduce 'terror factor' for the general populace.

structure_content.chapter_title: Move Not, for the Place is Holy
structure_content.summary: Dennis Garrett I° provides a technical analysis of the Enochian system of magic as derived from the original manuscripts of John Dee and Edward Kelly. He describes the specific equipment used, such as the 'Holy Table,' 'Seal of God,' and 'shewstone,' and details the 'Heptarchia Mystica' system, emphasizing its intended method of use and highlighting how later versions became incomplete and inaccurate.

key_concepts.definition: The development, evolution, and practice of the Black Arts, requiring a reasonable devotion of time and energy. It is seen as a path for self-creation and achieving personal gnosis.

A proposed term to replace 'Black Magic,' intended to be a more precise and internally consistent descriptor for the magical practices within the Temple of Set, moving away from 'shock-value' terminology.
The æonic Word for the I° degree, representing the will. Practitioners at this level must learn to locate, strengthen, and effectively use their will.

The æonic Word for the II° and III° degrees. For the II°, it signifies the aspiration to 'Indulge in their will and aspire to Xeper.' For the III°, it indicates the direct practice of 'Xeper' itself, which implies self-creation or becoming.
The æonic Word for the IV° degree, representing a further stage of evolution or understanding beyond Xeper.

The Temple's initiatory and educational structure, modeled on ancient Egyptian and Chinese 'schooling.' It involves assigning Priests to guide members through their individual evolution, with a progression toward a Master.

A structured path within the Temple of Set (Iº, IIº, IIIº, IVº) where each degree has specific lessons to learn and an associated æonic Word. Progression is contingent on mastering the lessons of the preceding degrees.

A basic human compulsion driven by a desire to be accepted, conform to others' ideas, or fear self-dependency. It can be transformed into 'security indulgence' by embracing one's true self and self-worth.

A basic human compulsion for frequent and intense pleasures (food, sex, etc.) seen as ends in themselves. It can be transformed into 'sensation indulgence' by viewing these experiences as additions and enhancements to life rather than desperate needs.

A basic human compulsion to control, driven by a need for mental aggrandizement or physical manifestation. It can be transformed into 'power indulgence' by recognizing that true power resides solely within the self.
A state of consciousness achieved by transcending compulsions, understanding one's inherent sufficiency, taking responsibility for one's reactions, and fully accepting oneself, leading to awakening.

As detailed by Dennis Garrett, the original magical system practiced by John Dee and Edward Kelly for contacting spirits. It involves specific ritual equipment and methodologies for achieving spirit manifestation, distinct from later distorted versions.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined emphasizes structured, self-directed magical evolution within the Temple of Set's initiatory framework. Members progress through degrees (Iº, IIº, IIIº, IVº), each with specific lessons and an æonic Word (Thelema, Xeper, Xem) to master. Guidance is provided by an assigned Priest through the 'Pyramid System.' Core operative work involves deep introspection and constant self-awareness to overcome self-deceit. A critical aspect is the transmutation of base compulsions (security, sensation, power) into conscious 'indulgence' to raise energy levels and attain the 'eternal now,' leading to self-integration as a 'sound magician.' Temple functions, conclaves, and contributions to internal publications (Ruby Tablet) are integral for shared experience and development. The text also advocates for precise terminology to enhance clarity and effectiveness in magical discourse.
tools: Setian: Crystal Tablet of Set (a foundational text with required readings), Ruby Tablet of Set (a platform for member contributions and ideas), The Scroll (internal publication), assigned Priests/Masters (for personal guidance in the Pyramid System).

Enochian: Holy Table (sweet wood, 2 cubits square, inscribed with Enochian letters, hexagram, seven talismans), Seal of God (1 1/8-inch thick wax disk, inscribed on both sides, with four smaller versions for table legs), shewstone (for spirit vision), white linen robe, silvered-edge book, breast talisman, gold ring, red silk (for insulation under the table), sigils for Heptarchia Mystica princes/servitors.
rituals: Setian: The text encourages Adepts to write their own rituals rather than rely solely on existing ones, emphasizing a personalized approach to magical practice. Temple functions and conclaves serve as communal magical undertakings.

Enochian: As described by Dennis Garrett, the system involves precise rituals for spirit contact. These include the construction and use of a 'Holy Table' with specific inscriptions, the 'Seal of God' (a wax disk), and a 'shewstone' for direct spirit manifestation. Specialized garb (white linen robe), talismans (for defense), and a gold ring are prescribed. The 'Heptarchia Mystica' system involves painting sigils for specific princes and servitors of the week.

relevant_quotes.text: One cannot be a Black Magician, i.e. Power of Darkness, part-time! If one is not prepared to devote a reasonable (note, I said 'reasonable') portion of one's time and energy to the development, evolution, and practice of the Black Arts, then he should get out of the Pit.
Is not a part of the Charge we have accepted from Set the responsibility to reach out to them and at least make them aware of our existence?
If you fail to learn the lessons that you must learn now, then you will have to go back and learn them later. Your steps forward are slowed as you step backward to pick up something you never had.

Only our fears are holding us back from taking the steps that will raise our energy levels and make us whole magicians. Let's explore the three basic compulsions that drive us and deplete our energy level rather than allowing us to indulge in them.
A sound magician is a mighty god!

The Enochian system of magic as it is known today is both incomplete and inaccurate. This is especially true of its origins, due to 300 years of distortion by notables from Meric. Causabon to Israel Regardie.
Nay, for they all played at it ... This is pure, this is holy, this is forever.

critical_analysis.relevance: This issue is highly relevant for understanding the internal dynamics and operational philosophy of the Temple of Set in its early years (1981). It provides direct guidance on member conduct, adherence to the initiatory system, ethical considerations regarding recruitment and terminology, and a historical/technical deep dive into Enochian magic. It reflects the Temple's emphasis on individual responsibility, self-evolution (Xeper), and the structured yet personalized approach to magical development.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is the membership of the Temple of Set, specifically focusing on Adepts (II°) and Priests (III°) for deeper internal discussions and guidance on the Temple's structure and magical practice. However, it also contains foundational advice for I° members regarding priorities and understanding the initiatory path. The Enochian article serves a more specialized, scholarly subset interested in historical magical traditions.
